Data Repositories
 
Repositories are locations for depositing and sharing data, and thereby obviously also a source to find data for potential re-use. They ensure long-term availability of data, and generally provide persistent identifiers (mainly DOI) for data citation.
 
The number of data repositories keeps increasing, re3data.org currently lists more than 2000 repositories. This compilation can be browsed by subject, content type or country, and further searched by e.g. type of data access (open, restricted, embargoed, closed) or metadata standards (generic e.g. Dublin Core and/or discipline-specific).
 
 
Repositories can be general (accepting a wide range of data from any scientist), institutional (also often content covering a wide range of scientific fields but data upload limited to a certain institution) or discipline-specific.
 
Discipline-specific repositories are recommended, as they provide more opportunities (but also obligations) to document data according to needs and standards of a scientific field. Data are also more likely to be discovered by other scientists working in the same or closely related fields. Various journals and publishers provide lists of recommended repositories:
 
Scientific Data (Springer Nature) recommended data repositories
 
PLoS ONE (applying to all PLOS journals)
 
PeerJ Data and Materials Sharing
 
Data Journals 
Data Journals are a relatively recent option for describing and documenting data, with such outputs being peer-reviewed and receiving a status comparable to conventional scientific manuscripts. The research context will be provided without detailed interpretation of the underlying data. The data themselves are generally deposited in a repository and linked from the data paper. Some data journals also accept articles describing data services or best practices in data sharing. The Humboldt University Berlin provides a list of data journals .
